title: Why there is nothing better than cycling (crashes aside)
text:
Life & Leisure Oct 28, 2019 — 9.27am Share

Thijs van der Heijden is a senior lecturer in finance at The University of Melbourne and founder of E-stralian, an e-bike leasing company.

What's your first memory of riding a bike?

Chasing tractors around my parents’ village in the Netherlands during harvest time on an orange 20-inch 1960s Mixte. I must have been around seven. It was fast and in retrospect very stylish, with a flatbar and white tyres. Those didn’t last too long from all the skidding, though.

How many bikes and how do you know when you have too many?

Three for myself; a Riese & Müller e-bike commuter, a Merida Scultura Team road bike for the weekends, and a Merida CX I keep in the Netherlands for when I’m visiting. I quite often ride our demo e-bikes, too. When you spend more time cleaning than riding, you have too many bikes.

How much did they cost?

The e-bike cost $11,000, the road bike $8000 and the CX $2000.

What's your dream bike and equipment?

Whenever I see a nice bike on the road I might say “Wow, that’d be cool to have”, but it never really changes how I feel about the bikes I actually own.

E-bikes are the ideal form of daily transport, says Thijs van der Heijden.

What kind of riding do you do?

I ride the e-bike pretty much anywhere for daily transport, it’s such an amazing tool. Being reasonably fit, I was initially sceptical about the benefits for myself. That changed one summer night when it was above 30 degrees. I had to go to a dinner party at the top of a hill in Melbourne’s eastern suburbs, a 15-kilometre ride. There was no way I could have ridden my regular bike there and arrive presentable at the other end. But with the e-bike, I could ride there in my work clothes. I sold my old hybrid and have never looked back. The road bike is for weekend riding with a small group.

Any tips to become a better rider?

First, just get out there more often. Second, get some technical skills coaching to make you more efficient.

How many kilometres a week do you ride?

About 150 to 200 a week all up.

Hills or the flat?

Rolling hills or short, not too steep, power climbs... The big mountains are fun, but I have to be fit to enjoy them.
description: A collision with a mountain has not deterred e-bike leasing company founder Thijs van der Heijden from riding whenever he can. He answers our Time Out Q&A.
